12 §1098.4.  Healthcare professional restrictions

13 A.  No physician or other medical healthcare professional shall provide

14 gender transition procedures to any person under eighteen years of age.

15 B.  No physician, mental health provider, or other medical healthcare

16 professional shall refer any person under eighteen years of age to any medical doctor

17 for gender transition procedures.

18 §1098.5.  Allocation of funds

19 A.  No public funds shall be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or

20 distributed to any entity, organization, or individual that provides gender transition

21 procedures to any minor. 

22 B.  Healthcare services furnished by or in a healthcare facility owned or

23 operated by the state or a parish or local government entity, or by a physician or

24 other individual employed by the state or a parish or local government entity, shall

25 not include gender transition procedures for minors.

26 §1098.6.  Healthcare coverage; insurance policy restrictions

27 No insurance policy covering healthcare costs for eligible children in this

28 state shall include reimbursement for gender transition procedures for any person

29 under eighteen years of age.

1 §1098.7.  Disciplinary actions; judicial relief

2 A.  Any provision of gender transition procedures to a person under eighteen

3 years of age shall be considered unprofessional conduct and shall be subject to

4 discipline by the licensing entity with jurisdiction over the physician, mental health

5 provider, or other medical healthcare professional.  An adverse ruling by the

6 appropriate licensing board shall result in immediate revocation of the license or

7 certificate of the physician or other healthcare professional. 

8 B.  A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this Part as a

9 claim or defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding and obtain compensatory

10 damages, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief. 

11 C.  A person shall be required to bring a claim for a violation of this Part no

12 later than thirty years after the day the cause of action occurs.  A minor may bring

13 an action before reaching eighteen years of age through a parent or guardian, and

14 may bring an action in the minor's own name upon reaching eighteen years of age

15 at any time from that point until thirty years after.

16 D.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action pursuant to this

17 Section may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding

18 without regard to whether the person commencing the action has sought or exhausted

19 available administrative remedies.

20 E.  In any action or proceeding to enforce a provision of this Part, a

21 prevailing party who establishes a violation of this Part shall be entitled to recover

22 reasonable attorney's fees.

23 F.  The attorney general may bring an action to enforce compliance with this

24 Part.  Nothing in this Part shall be construed to deny, impair, or otherwise affect any

25 right or authority of the attorney general, the state, or any agency, officer, or

26 employee of this state, acting under any provision of the Louisiana Revised Statutes

27 of 1950, to institute or intervene in any proceeding.

DIGEST

The digest printed below was prepared by House Legislative Services.  It constitutes no part
of the legislative instrument.  The keyword, one-liner, abstract, and digest do not constitute
part of the law or proof or indicia of legislative intent.  [R.S. 1:13(B) and 24:177(E)]

HB 463 Original 2023 Regular Session Firment

Abstract:  Establishes the "Save Adolescents from Experimentation Act" in Louisiana and
prohibits procedures that alter the gender of minors.

Proposed law states that the risks associated with the allowance of irreversible, permanently
sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgery outweigh the scientific benefits.

Proposed law defines "biological sex", "birth sex","sex""cross-sex hormone", "gender",
"gender reassignment surgery", "gender transition", "gender transition procedures", "genital
gender reassignment surgery", "medical healthcare professional", "non-genital gender
reassignment surgery", "physician""puberty-blocking drugs", and "public funds".

Proposed law prohibits any physician or other medical healthcare professional from
performing any gender transition procedures on any person under 18 years of age or
referring any person under 18 years of age to any medical doctor for gender transition
procedures.

Proposed law prohibits the use of any public funds or funds allocated to any entity,
organization, or individual that provides a gender reassignment procedure. 

Proposed law excludes gender transition procedures for any person under 18 years of age
from healthcare coverage reimbursement.

Proposed law provides that any provision of gender transition procedures to a person under
18 years of age shall be considered unprofessional conduct and shall be subject to discipline
by the licensing entity with jurisdiction over the physician, mental health provider, or other
medical healthcare professional. 

Proposed law provides for legal action to be brought upon violation of proposed law.

(Adds R.S. 40:1098.1-1098.7)

GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF NORTH CAROLINA 

SESSION 2023 

S D 

SENATE BILL DRS55047-NB-40A  

 

 

 

Short Title: Medical Treatment for Minors Act. (Public) 

Sponsors: Senators Krawiec, Burgin, and Corbin (Primary Sponsors). 

Referred to:  

 

*DRS55047-NB-40A* 

A BILL TO BE ENTITLED 1 

AN ACT TO ESTABLISH GOVERNING PROVISIONS FOR THE TREATMENT OF 2 

GENDER DYSPHORIA FOR PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE. 3 

Whereas, gender dysphoria is an extremely complex and challenging mental health 4 

disorder; and 5 

Whereas, patients seeking gender transition procedure often suffer from significant 6 

mental and social stressors; and 7 

Whereas, it is in the State's interest to protect minor patients from permanent harm; 8 

Now, therefore, 9 

The General Assembly of North Carolina enacts: 10 

SECTION 1.  Chapter 90 of the General Statutes is amended by adding a new Article 11 

to read: 12 

"Article 1M. 13 

"Minor Protection Act. 14 

"§ 90-21.140.  Definitions. 15 

The following definitions apply in this Article: 16 

(1) Biological sex. – The biological indication of male and female in the context 17 

of reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally 18 

occurring sex hormones, gonads, and nonambiguous internal and external 19 

genitalia present at birth, without regard to an individual's psychological, 20 

chosen, or subjective experience of gender. 21 

(2) Cross-sex hormones. – Testosterone or other androgens given to biological 22 

females in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur 23 

naturally in healthy biological sex females, and estrogen given to biological 24 

males in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur 25 

naturally in healthy biological sex males. 26 

(3) Department. – The Department of Health and Human Services. 27 

(4) Gender. – The psychological, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of being 28 

male or female. 29 

(5) Gender reassignment surgery. – Any medical or surgical service that seeks to 30 

surgically alter or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or 31 

features that are typical for the individual's biological sex, in order to instill or 32 

create physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex different 33 

from the individual's biological sex, including a genital or non-genital gender 34 

reassignment surgery as defined in this section. 35 

FILED SENATE
Apr 4, 2023
S.B. 560

PRINCIPAL CLERK



General Assembly Of North Carolina Session 2023 

Page 2  DRS55047-NB-40A 

(6) Gender transition. – The process in which a person goes from identifying with 1 

and living as a gender that corresponds to his or her biological sex to 2 

identifying with and living as a gender different from his or her biological sex, 3 

and may involve social, legal, or physical changes. 4 

(7) Gender transition procedure. – Any medical or surgical service, including, 5 

without limitation, genital gender reassignment surgery and non-genital 6 

reassignment surgery, physician's services, inpatient and outpatient hospital 7 

services, or prescribed drugs related to gender transition that seeks to do any 8 

of the following: 9 

a. Alter or remove physical or anatomical characteristics or features that 10 

are typical for the individual's biological sex. 11 

b. Instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics that 12 

resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex, 13 

including, without limitation, medical services that provide 14 

puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or other mechanisms to 15 

promote the development of feminizing or masculinizing features in 16 

the opposite biological sex. 17 

For the purposes of this definition, the term "gender transition procedure" shall 18 

not include any of the following: (i) services to persons born with a medically 19 

verifiable disorder of sex development, including a person with external 20 

biological sex characteristics that are unresolvedly ambiguous, such as those 21 

born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with 22 

under-virilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue; (ii) services 23 

provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual 24 

development that the physician has determined through genetic or 25 

biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex chromosome 26 

structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action; (iii) 27 

the treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused 28 

by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, 29 

whether or not the gender transition procedure was performed in accordance 30 

with State and federal law or whether or not funding for the gender transition 31 

procedure is permissible under this Article; (iv) breast reduction procedures 32 

for a female patient causing a physical disorder; or (v) any procedure 33 

undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, physical 34 

injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the 35 

individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily 36 

function unless surgery is performed. 37 

(8) Genital gender reassignment surgery. – A gender reassignment surgery 38 

performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition, 39 

including, without limitation, any of the following: 40 

a. Surgical procedures such as penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, 41 

clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male patients or 42 

hysterectomy or ovariectomy for biologically female patients. 43 

b. Reconstruction of the fixed part of the urethra with or without a 44 

metoidioplasty. 45 

c. Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection or 46 

testicular prostheses for biologically female patients. 47 

(9) Health care provider. – A person who is licensed, certified, or otherwise 48 

authorized by the laws of this State to administer health care in the ordinary 49 

course of the practice of his or her profession. 50 

(10) Minor. – An individual who is younger than 18 years of age. 51 



General Assembly Of North Carolina Session 2023 

DRS55047-NB-40A  Page 3 

(11) Non-genital gender reassignment surgery. – A gender reassignment surgery 1 

performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition, 2 

including, without limitation, any of the following: 3 

a. Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as 4 

augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, 5 

lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal 6 

augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures. 7 

b. Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as 8 

subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, 9 

pectoral implants, or various aesthetic procedures. 10 

(12) Pediatric psychiatrist. – A physician who has completed a child and adolescent 11 

psychiatry residency and certification exam and specializes in the diagnosis 12 

and the treatment of disorders of thinking, feeling, or behavior affecting 13 

children, adolescents, and their families, using knowledge of biological, 14 

psychological, and social factors in working with patients. 15 

(13) Physician. – An individual licensed to practice medicine under Article 1A of 16 

Chapter 90 of the General Statutes. 17 

(14) Puberty-blocking drugs. – Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or 18 

other synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone 19 

secretion and therefore testosterone secretion, or synthetic drugs used in 20 

biological females which stop the production of estrogens and progesterone, 21 

when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children for the 22 

purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition. 23 

(15) Public funds. – State, county, or local government monies, in addition to any 24 

department, agency, or instrumentality authorized or appropriated under State 25 

law or derived from any fund in which such monies are deposited. 26 

"§ 90-21.141.  Limitations of certain practices and health care services. 27 

(a) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, it shall be unlawful for any physician or 28 

other health care provider to provide gender transition procedures to any individual under 18 29 

years of age, except as provided in this section. A physician or other health care provider shall 30 

not refer any individual under 18 years of age to any health care provider for gender transition 31 

procedures. Any counseling or treatment rendered under this Article shall not be via telehealth 32 

and must be rendered through face-to-face encounters. 33 

(b) It shall not be unlawful for a physician to perform a gender transition procedure to an 34 

individual under 18 years of age, if all of the following conditions are satisfied: 35 

(1) Prior to the gender transition procedure, at least two physicians, including a 36 

pediatric psychiatrist who has performed a standard psychiatric clinical 37 

evaluation inclusive of differential diagnosis must certify and document in 38 

writing that the patient suffers from a condition that would benefit from a 39 

gender transition procedure. The certifying pediatric psychiatrist shall not be 40 

employed by the same practice or institution as the certifying physician. 41 

(2) Both parents must sign the standardized consent form provided by the 42 

physician performing the gender transition procedure. 43 

(3) The patient under 18 years of age must sign the standardized consent form 44 

provided by the physician performing the gender transition procedure. 45 

(4) For the duration of six months preceding the gender transition procedure, the 46 

patient must receive regular care consisting of at least monthly appointments 47 

from a pediatric psychiatrist. 48 

(5) The physician and the pediatric psychiatrist must separately document in 49 

writing the need for ongoing therapy every six months. 50 



General Assembly Of North Carolina Session 2023 

Page 4  DRS55047-NB-40A 

(6) The patient must receive ongoing care from a pediatric psychiatrist until the 1 

patient attains the age of majority. 2 

(c) A physician or other health care provider shall not be prohibited from providing any 3 

of the following procedures to a minor: 4 

(1) Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex 5 

development, including a person with external biological sex characteristics 6 

that are unresolvedly ambiguous, such as those born with 46 XX 7 

chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with under-virilization, 8 

or having both ovarian and testicular tissue. 9 

(2) Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of 10 

sexual development that the physician has determined through genetic or 11 

biochemical testing that the person does not have normal sex chromosome 12 

structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action. 13 

(3) The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been 14 

caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, 15 

whether or not the gender transition procedure was performed in accordance 16 

with State and federal law or whether or not funding for the gender transition 17 

procedure is permissible under this Article. 18 

(4) Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical 19 

disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a 20 

physician, place the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of 21 

major bodily function unless surgery is performed. 22 

(d) Notwithstanding any provision of this Article, a physician or health care provider may 23 

provide health care services, treatments, or procedures that directly treat a physical disorder, 24 

injury, or illness that does not put the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of 25 

major bodily function, if the physical disorder, injury, or illness is for the purposes of gender 26 

transition. 27 

(e) A State, county, or local health care facility, physician, or health care provider shall 28 

not perform gender transition procedures for a minor, except as provided in this Article. 29 

(f) Nothing in this Article shall be construed to require a physician or health care provider 30 

to perform a gender transition procedure. 31 

"§ 90-21.142.  Limitation on use of State funds for gender transition procedures. 32 

Public funds shall not be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or distributed to any entity, 33 

organization, or individual that provides gender transition procedures to a minor. 34 

"§ 90-21.143.  Standardized consent form. 35 

(a) The Department shall develop and maintain a standardized consent form for parents 36 

to sign prior to a gender transition procedure under this Article. The Department shall also 37 

develop and maintain a standardized consent form for a patient under 18 years of age to sign 38 

prior to a gender transition procedure. 39 

(b) The minor and the minor's parents must sign the consent form at least 30 days before 40 

the first treatment of the gender transition procedure and at every subsequent medical visit for 41 

treatment. 42 

(c) The consent form must comply with all of the following: 43 

(1) Printed in justified typeface and be printed in at least 14-point sized font. 44 

(2) Contain the following statement: 45 

"If your child begins one (1) of these treatments, it may actually worsen the 46 

discordance and thus increase the likelihood that your child will need 47 

additional and more serious interventions to address the worsening condition. 48 

For example, if your child begins socially transitioning or taking puberty 49 

blockers, that treatment may significantly increase the likelihood that your 50 

child's discordance will worsen and lead to your child eventually seeking 51 



General Assembly Of North Carolina Session 2023 

DRS55047-NB-40A  Page 5 

cross-sex hormones or even surgery to remove some of your child's body 1 

parts. Sweden, Finland, and the United Kingdom have conducted systematic 2 

reviews of evidence and conclude that there is no evidence that the potential 3 

benefits of puberty blockers and cross-sex hormones for this purpose 4 

outweigh the known or assumed risks. 5 

Medical authorities in Sweden, Finland, Norway, and the United Kingdom 6 

have since recommended psychotherapy as the first line of treatment for youth 7 

gender dysphoria with drugs and surgeries reserved as a measure of last resort. 8 

Medical authorities in France have advised great caution when prescribing 9 

hormones for gender dysphoria. 10 

There are people who underwent gender transition treatments as minors and 11 

later regretted that decision and the physical harm that these treatments 12 

caused, and the total percentage of people who experience this regret is 13 

unknown. Some estimate that the rate is below two percent (2%), but that 14 

estimate is based on studies done on adults who transitioned as adults or on 15 

minors who transitioned under highly restrictive and controlled conditions. 16 

Sometimes gender transition treatments have been proposed as a way to 17 

reduce the chances of a minor committing suicide due to discordance between 18 

the minor's sex and his or her perception, but the rates of actual suicide from 19 

this discordance remain extremely low. Furthermore, as recognized by health 20 

authorities in Europe, there is no evidence that suicidality is caused by 21 

unaffirmed gender or that gender transition treatments are causally linked to a 22 

reduction in serious suicidal attempts or ideations." 23 

(3) If the treatment involves puberty blockers, the consent form shall contain the 24 

following additional statement: 25 

"Puberty blockers are not approved for this purpose by the United States Food 26 

and Drug Administration, which is the federal agency that determines which 27 

drugs are safe and effective for humans to use. Claims about puberty blockers' 28 

safety and efficacy are based on their use for precocious puberty, a different 29 

condition in which normal puberty is allowed to resume once the patient 30 

reaches the appropriate age. Studies on the benefits of using puberty blockers 31 

for gender dysphoria are notoriously weak. Puberty blockers are not fully 32 

reversible because, among other risks, puberty blockers may intensify a 33 

minor's discordance and cause it to persist. Puberty blockers increase the risk 34 

of your child being sterilized, meaning that he or she will never be able to 35 

have children. Puberty blockers may also cause diminished bone density for 36 

your child, increasing the risk of fracture and early osteoporosis. Puberty 37 

blockers may also prevent your child from ever being able to engage in sexual 38 

activity or achieve orgasm for the rest of your child's life. There is no research 39 

on the long-term risks to minors of persistent exposure to puberty blockers. 40 

The full effects of puberty blockers on brain development and cognition are 41 

unknown." 42 

(4) If the treatment involves cross-sex hormones, the consent form shall contain 43 

the following additional statement: 44 

"The use of cross-sex hormones in males is associated with numerous health 45 

risks, such as thromboembolic disease, including, without limitation, blood 46 

clots; cholelithiasis, including gallstones; coronary artery disease, including, 47 

without limitation, heart attacks; macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the 48 

pituitary gland; cerebrovascular disease, including, without limitation, 49 

strokes; hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the 50 

blood; breast cancer; and irreversible infertility. The use of cross-sex 51 



General Assembly Of North Carolina Session 2023 

Page 6  DRS55047-NB-40A 

hormones in females is associated with risks of erythrocytosis, which is an 1 

increase in red blood cells; severe liver dysfunction; coronary artery disease, 2 

including, without limitation, heart attacks; hypertension; and increased risk 3 

of breast and uterine cancers. Once a minor begins cross-sex hormones, the 4 

minor may need to continue taking those hormones for many years and 5 

possibly for the remainder of the minor's life. The cost of these hormones may 6 

be tens of thousands of dollars. If the use of cross-sex hormones leads to 7 

surgery, the total cost of transitioning may exceed one hundred thousand 8 

dollars ($100,000)." 9 

(5) If the treatment involves a surgical procedure, the consent form shall contain 10 

the following additional statement: 11 

"The dangers, risks, complications, and long-term concerns associated with 12 

these types of procedures are almost entirely unknown. There are no long-term 13 

studies on either the effectiveness or safety of these surgical procedures." 14 

"§ 90-21.144.  Civil remedies. 15 

(a) Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, a physician or health care 16 

provider who performs a gender transition procedure is liable to the minor if the minor is injured, 17 

including, without limitation, any physical, psychological, emotional, or physiological injury, by 18 

the gender transition procedure, related treatment, or the effects of the gender transition 19 

procedure or related treatment. 20 

(b) A minor injured as provided under subsection (a) of this section, or a representative 21 

of the minor, may bring a civil action against the physician or health care provider who performed 22 

the gender transition procedure on the minor in a court of competent jurisdiction and seek all of 23 

the following: 24 

(1) Declaratory relief or injunctive relief. 25 

(2) Compensatory damages. 26 

(3) Punitive damages. 27 

(4) Attorneys' fees and costs. 28 

(c) A claim of action arising from this section must be filed within 15 years after the date 29 

on which the minor attains the age of majority or the date the minor would have attained the age 30 

of majority if the minor predeceases prior to that date. 31 

(d) It shall be a defense to a claim filed in accordance with this section, if the physician 32 

or health care provider (i) documented the minor's perceived gender during the entirety of the 33 

course of treatment and the minor's perceived gender was different from the minor's biological 34 

sex, (ii) the physician and pediatric psychiatrist certified in writing that the gender transition 35 

procedure was the only way to treat the minor's condition, (iii) that the minor suffered from no 36 

other mental health concerns or conditions, including depression, eating disorders, autism, 37 

attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, intellectual disability, or psychotic disorders, and (iv) the 38 

physician received the consent form from the minor and the minor's parents in accordance with 39 

this Article. 40 

"§ 90-21.145.  Violation; enforcement. 41 

(a) A violation of this Article by a physician or other health care provider shall be 42 

considered unprofessional conduct and shall be subject to revocation of licensure and other 43 

appropriate discipline by the North Carolina Medical Board, North Carolina Board of Nursing, 44 

or other appropriate licensing board, as applicable. 45 

(b) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this Article as a claim or 46 

defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding and obtain compensatory damages, injunctive 47 

relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief. 48 

(c) A certification for a gender transition procedure by a physician under this Article is 49 

not an affirmative defense to a claim brought under this Chapter or other applicable State or 50 

federal law for medical malpractice or other civil claims of action. 51 



General Assembly Of North Carolina Session 2023 

DRS55047-NB-40A  Page 7 

"§ 90-21.146.  Severability. 1 

If any one or more provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or word of this 2 

Article or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is found to be unconstitutional, 3 

the same is hereby declared to be severable, and the balance of this Article shall remain effective, 4 

notwithstanding such unconstitutionality. The General Assembly hereby declares that it would 5 

have passed this Article, and each provision, section, subsection, sentence, clause, phrase, or 6 

word thereof, irrespective of the fact that any one or more provision, section, subsection, 7 

sentence, clause, phrase, or word be declared unconstitutional." 8 

SECTION 2.  G.S. 90-21.5 reads as rewritten: 9 

"§ 90-21.5.  Minor's consent sufficient for certain medical health services. 10 

(a) Subject to subsection (a1) of this section, any minor may give effective consent to a 11 

physician licensed to practice medicine in North Carolina for medical health services for the 12 

prevention, diagnosis and treatment of (i) venereal disease and other diseases reportable under 13 

G.S. 130A-135, (ii) pregnancy, (iii) abuse of controlled substances or alcohol, and (iv) emotional 14 

disturbance. This section does not authorize the inducing of an abortion, performance of a 15 

sterilization operation, or admission to a 24-hour facility licensed under Article 2 of Chapter 16 

122C of the General Statutes except as provided in G.S. 122C-223. This section does not prohibit 17 

the admission of a minor to a treatment facility upon his own written application in an emergency 18 

situation as authorized by G.S. 122C-223. 19 

(a1) Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, a health care provider 20 

shall obtain written consent from a parent or legal guardian prior to administering any vaccine 21 

that has been granted emergency use authorization and is not yet fully approved by the United 22 

States Food and Drug Administration to an individual under 18 years of age. 23 

(b) Any minor who is emancipated may consent to any medical treatment, dental and 24 

health services for himself or for his child. 25 

(c) This section shall not apply to any gender transition procedure as defined in 26 

G.S. 90-21.140." 27 

SECTION 3.  The North Carolina Medical Board shall adopt temporary rules to 28 

implement the provisions of this act. 29 

SECTION 4.  This act becomes effective October 1, 2023. 30

column4: Rhode Island's Children Deserve Help Not Harm Act -- Minor's Gender Transition
column5: Prohibits gender transition procedures for all minors, uses of public funds for that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of limitation, right to a civil action for damages.
column20:
2023 -- S 0958 
======== 

LC001556 

======== 

S T A T E   O F   R H O D E   I S L A N D  

IN GENERAL ASSEMBLY 

JANUARY SESSION, A.D. 2023 

____________ 

 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE 

HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION 

Introduced By: Senator E Morgan 

Date Introduced: May 01, 2023 

Referred To: Senate Judiciary 

 

 

It is enacted by the General Assembly as follows: 

SECTION 1. Legislative findings and purpose. 1 

The general assembly finds that: 2 

(1) Rhode Island has a compelling government interest protecting the health and safety of 3 

its citizens, especially vulnerable children;  4 

(2) Only a small percentage of the American population experiences distress identifying 5 

with their biological sex;  6 

(3) For the small percentage of children who are gender nonconforming or experience 7 

distress identifying with their biological sex, studies consistently demonstrate that the majority 8 

come to embrace their biological sex in adolescence or adulthood, thereby rendering most medical 9 

physiological interventions unnecessary; 10 

(4) Scientific studies show that individuals experiencing distress identifying with their 11 

biological sex have often experienced severe psychopathology preceding their gender dysphoria, 12 

which indicates these individuals could benefit greatly from access to mental healthcare services; 13 

(5) Even among individuals who have undergone inpatient gender reassignment 14 

procedures, suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, and mortality rates remain markedly elevated 15 

above the background population; 16 

(6) Some healthcare professionals are prescribing puberty-blocking drugs such as 17 

gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, in order to delay the natural onset or progression of 18 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 2 of 11 

puberty in children, who experience distress identifying with their biological sex: 1 

(i) Puberty-blocking drugs are being prescribed, despite the lack of any long-term 2 

longitudinal studies evaluating the risks and benefits of using these drugs for the treatment of such 3 

distress or gender dysphoria; and 4 

(ii) Puberty-blocking drugs are being prescribed in an off-label and experimental manner 5 

on children; 6 

(7) Some healthcare professionals are also prescribing cross-sex hormones for children 7 

who are experiencing distress identifying with their biological sex, despite the fact no randomized 8 

clinical trials have been conducted on the efficacy or safety of the use of cross-sex hormones in 9 

adults or children for the purpose of gender transition; 10 

(8) The use of cross-sex hormones comes with serious known risks: 11 

(i) For biological females, some risks may include; 12 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 13 

(B) Severe liver dysfunction; 14 

(C) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 15 

(D) Increased risk of breast, cervical, and uterine cancers; 16 

(E) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 17 

(F) Hypertension; 18 

(G) Erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells; 19 

(H) Sleep apnea; 20 

(I) Type 2 diabetes; 21 

(J) Loss of bone density; 22 

(K) Destabilization of psychiatric disorders; and 23 

(ii) For biological males, some risks may include: 24 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 25 

(B) Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; 26 

(C) Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; 27 

(D) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 28 

(E) Type 2 diabetes; 29 

(F) Breast cancer; 30 

(G) Macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland; 31 

(H) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; and 32 

(I) Hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood; 33 

(9) Genital and non-genital gender reassignment surgeries are generally not recommended 34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 3 of 11 

for children, although evidence indicates referrals for children to have such surgeries are becoming 1 

more frequent; 2 

(10) Genital gender reassignment surgery includes several irreversible invasive procedures 3 

for males and females and involves the alteration of biologically healthy and functional body parts. 4 

These procedures are generally irreversible; 5 

(i) For biological males, surgery may involve: 6 

(A) Genital reconstruction, including a penectomy, which is the removal of the penis; 7 

(B) Orchiectomy, which is the removal of the testicles; 8 

(C) Vaginoplasty, which is the construction of a vagina-like structure, typically through a 9 

penile inversion procedure; 10 

(D) Clitoroplasty which is the construction of a clitoris-like structure; and 11 

(E) Vulvoplasty, which is the construction of a vulva-like structure; 12 

(ii) For biological females, surgery may involve: 13 

(A) Hysterectomy or oophorectomy; 14 

(B) Reconstruction of the urethra; 15 

(C) Genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, which is the 16 

construction of a penis-like structure; 17 

(D) Vaginectomy, which is the removal of the vagina; 18 

(E) Scrotoplasty, which is the construction of a scrotum-like structure; and 19 

(F) Implantation of erection and/or testicular prosthesis; 20 

(iii) The complications, risks, and long-term care concerns associated with genital sex 21 

reassignment surgery, for both males and females, are numerous and complex; 22 

(iv) Non-genital sex reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures for males 23 

and females and also involves the alteration or removal of biologically health, and functional body 24 

parts: 25 

(A) For biological males, this surgery may involve: 26 

(I) Augmentation mammoplasty; 27 

(II) Facial feminization surgery; 28 

(III) Liposuction; 29 

(IV) Lipofilling; 30 

(V) Voice feminization surgery; 31 

(VI) Thyroid cartilage reduction; 32 

(VII) Gluteal augmentation; 33 

(VIII) Hair reconstruction; and 34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 4 of 11 

(IX) Other aesthetic procedures; 1 

(B) For biological females, this surgery may involve: 2 

(I) Subcutaneous mastectomy; 3 

(II) Voice masculinization surgery; 4 

(III) Liposuction; 5 

(IV) Lipofilling; 6 

(V) Pectoral implants; and 7 

(VI) Other aesthetic procedures; 8 

(11) It is an accepted principle of economics and public policy that when a service or 9 

product is subsidized or reimbursed, demand for that service or product increases; and 10 

(12) It is of grave concern to this general assembly that the medical community is allowing 11 

individuals, who experience distress identifying with their biological sex, to be subjects of 12 

irreversible and drastic non-genital gender reassignment surgery and irreversible, permanently 13 

sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgeries, despite the lack of studies showing that such 14 

extreme interventions have benefits that outweigh their risks or chances of cure. In fact, they may 15 

increase the risk of suicide. 16 

SECTION 2. Title 23 of the General Laws entitled "HEALTH AND SAFETY" is hereby 17 

amended by adding thereto the following chapter: 18 

CHAPTER 99 19 

RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE HELP NOT HARM ACT 20 

23-99-1. Title.     21 

This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Rhode Island's Children Deserve Help 22 

Not Harm Act". 23 

23-99-2. Definitions.     24 

The following definitions apply in the interpretation of the provisions of this chapter: 25 

(1) "Biological sex" means the biological indication of male and female in the context of 26 

reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, 27 

gonads, and nonambiguous internal and external genitalia, present at birth, including secondary sex 28 

characteristics. 29 

(2) "Cross-sex hormones" means: 30 

(i) Testosterone or other androgens given to biological females in amounts that create 31 

serum levels greater than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological females, which may 32 

include without limitation, the following risks: 33 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 5 of 11 

(B) Severe liver dysfunction; 1 

(C) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 2 

(D) Increased risk of breast, cervical, and uterine cancers; 3 

(E) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 4 

(F) Hypertension; 5 

(G) Erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells; 6 

(H) Sleep apnea; 7 

(I) Type 2 diabetes; 8 

(J) Loss of bone density; and 9 

(K) Destabilization of psychiatric disorders; and 10 

(ii) Estrogen given to biological males, in amounts that create serum levels greater than 11 

would normally occur naturally in healthy biological males, which may include without limitation 12 

the following risks: 13 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 14 

(B) Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; 15 

(C) Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; 16 

(D) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 17 

(E) Type 2 diabetes; 18 

(F) Breast cancer; 19 

(G) Macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland; 20 

(H) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; and 21 

(I) Hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood. 22 

(3) "Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social and cultural aspects of being male 23 

and female. 24 

(4) "Gender reassignment surgery" means any surgical service that seeks to surgically alter 25 

or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or features, that are typical for the 26 

individual's biological sex, in order to instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics, 27 

that resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex, including without limitation, 28 

genital or non-genital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an 29 

individual with a gender transition. 30 

(5) "Gender transition" means the process in which a person goes from identifying with 31 

and living as a gender that corresponds to their biological sex, and may involve social, legal, or 32 

physical changes. 33 

(6) "Gender transition procedures" means any medical or surgical service provided or 34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 6 of 11 

performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition: 1 

(i) Gender transition procedures include, without limitation, physician's services, inpatient 2 

and outpatient hospital services, puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or genital or non-3 

genital gender reassignment surgery; 4 

(ii) Gender transition procedures do not include: 5 

(A) Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, 6 

including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such 7 

as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with 8 

undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue; 9 

(B) Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual 10 

development, that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the 11 

person does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid production, or sex steroid 12 

hormone action; 13 

(C) The acute and chronic treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has 14 

been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, whether or not 15 

the gender transition procedure, was performed in accordance with state and federal law or whether 16 

or not funding for the gender transition procedure is permissible under this chapter; or  17 

(D) Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, 18 

physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the individual in 19 

imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function, unless surgery is performed. 20 

(7) "Genital gender reassignment surgery" means a surgical procedure performed for the 21 

purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition, including, without limitation: 22 

(i) Surgical procedures such as a penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or 23 

vulvoplasty for biologically male patients; or 24 

(ii) Surgical procedures such as hysterectomy, oophorectomy, reconstruction of the 25 

urethra, metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection 26 

and/or testicular protheses for biologically female patients. 27 

(8) "Non-genital gender reassignment surgery" means surgical procedures performed for 28 

the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition, including, without 29 

limitation: 30 

(i) Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, 31 

facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice feminization surgery, thyroid cartilage 32 

reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or 33 

(ii) Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, 34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 7 of 11 

voice masculinization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or various aesthetic 1 

procedures. 2 

(9) "Physician" means a person who is licensed to practice medicine in this state. 3 

(10) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or other 4 

synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion and therefore 5 

testosterone production, or synthetic drugs used in biological females, which stop the production 6 

of estrogen and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children, for 7 

the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition. 8 

(11) "Public funds" means state or local government monies, in addition to any department, 9 

agency, or instrumentality authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund in 10 

which monies are deposited. 11 

23-99-3. Gender transition procedures for minors prohibited.     12 

(a) A physician or other healthcare professional shall not provide gender transition 13 

procedures to any individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 14 

(b) A healthcare institution or entity shall not facilitate the provision of gender transition 15 

procedures to any individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 16 

23-99-4. Insurance coverage for gender transition procedures for minors prohibited.     17 

(a) A health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing healthcare 18 

coverage in this state shall not include reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a person 19 

under eighteen (18) years of age. 20 

(b) A health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing healthcare 21 

coverage in this state is not required to provide coverage for gender transition procedures. 22 

(c) A federal health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing 23 

healthcare coverage, such as TRICare or Veterans Administration Healthcare, shall not include 24 

reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a person under eighteen (18) years of age in 25 

this state. 26 

23-99-5. Prohibition on aiding or abetting.     27 

(a) A person or entity shall not knowingly engage in conduct that aids or abets the 28 

performance or inducement of gender transition procedures, to any individual under eighteen (18) 29 

years of age, including employees of other state governments, the federal government, or foreign 30 

governments. 31 

(b) This provision shall not apply to any first amendment-protected speech.  32 

(c) No parent of a child victim shall be held liable under this section. 33 

23-99-6. Prohibition on use of public funds for gender transition.     34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 8 of 11 

(a) Public funds shall not be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or distributed to any 1 

entity, organization, or individual that provides gender transition procedures to an individual under 2 

eighteen (18) years of age. 3 

(b) Healthcare services furnished in the following situations shall not include gender 4 

transition procedures to an individual under eighteen (18) years of age: 5 

(1) By or in a facility owned by the state or a local government; or  6 

(2) By a physician or other healthcare professional employed by the state or local 7 

government. 8 

(c) An amount paid by an individual or an entity, during a taxable year, for provision of 9 

gender transition procedures or as premiums for healthcare coverage, that includes coverage for 10 

gender transition procedures, is not tax-deductible. 11 

(d) The state Medicaid program shall not reimburse or provide coverage for gender 12 

transition procedures to an individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 13 

23-99-7. Gender transition procedures on minors constitute unprofessional and 14 

reckless conduct.     15 

Any referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to an individual, under 16 

eighteen (18) years of age, is unprofessional conduct and is subject to discipline by the appropriate 17 

licensing entity or disciplinary review board, with competent jurisdiction in this state. 18 

23-99-8. Enforcement actions for recovery of damages suffered as a result of gender 19 

transition procedures on minors.     20 

(a) Statute of limitations: 21 

(1) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an individual under eighteen (18) years of 22 

age may bring an action, throughout their minority, through a parent or next friend, and may bring 23 

an action in their own name, upon reaching the age of majority at any time from that point until 24 

thirty (30) years after reaching the age of majority. 25 

(2) Exceptions: 26 

(i) If at the time the person abused attains the age of eighteen (18) years or they are under 27 

other legal disability, the limitation period under subsection (a)(1) of this section does not begin to 28 

run until the removal of the disability; and 29 

(ii) The limitation period in subsection (a)(1) of this section does not run during a time 30 

period when the individual is subject to threats, intimidation, manipulation, fraudulent 31 

concealment, or fraud perpetrated by the physician or other healthcare professional, who prescribed 32 

or otherwise provided gender transition procedures or by any person, acting in the interest of the 33 

physician or other healthcare professional. 34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 9 of 11 

(b) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this chapter, as a claim or 1 

defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding. 2 

(1) The following damages may be awarded to the claimant: 3 

(i) Compensatory damages, including, but not limited to: 4 

(A) Pain and suffering; 5 

(B) Loss of reputation; 6 

(C) Loss of income; and 7 

(D) Loss of consortium, including, but not limited to, the loss of expectation of sharing 8 

parenthood; 9 

(ii) Injunctive relief; 10 

(iii) Declaratory relief; 11 

(iv) Punitive damages; 12 

(v) Any other appropriate relief; and 13 

(vi) A prevailing party, who establishes a violation of this chapter shall recover reasonable 14 

attorneys' fees and cost. 15 

(c) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action under this chapter, may be 16 

commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding, without regard to whether the 17 

person commencing the action has sought or exhausted available administrative remedies. 18 

(d) The attorney general may bring an action to enforce compliance with this chapter. 19 

(e) This chapter does not deny, impair, or otherwise affect any right or authority of the 20 

attorney general, the State of Rhode Island, or any agency, officer, or employee of the state, acting 21 

under any law, other than this chapter, to institute or intervene in any proceeding. 22 

23-99-9. Right of intervention.     23 

The general assembly, by joint resolution, may appoint one or more of its members who 24 

sponsored or cosponsored this chapter in their official capacity, to intervene or defend the chapter 25 

as a matter of right, in any case in which the constitutionality or enforceability of this chapter, any 26 

portion thereof, or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant hereto, is challenged. 27 

23-99-10. Severability.     28 

Any provision of this chapter held to be invalid or unenforceable by its terms, or as applied 29 

to any person or circumstance, shall be construed so as to give it the maximum effect, permitted by 30 

law, unless such holding, shall be one of utter invalidity or unenforceability, in which event such 31 

provision shall be deemed severable herefrom and shall not affect the remainder hereof or the 32 

application of such provision to other persons not similarly situated to or to other, dissimilar 33 

circumstances. 34 



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 10 of 11 

23-99-11. Effective date.     1 

This act shall take effect on January 1, 2024, in order that minors in this state currently 2 

using puberty-blocking drugs or cross-sex hormones, shall have the time for appropriate medication 3 

tapering and discontinuation, under the care of their physician or other healthcare professional. 4 

SECTION 3. This act shall take effect on January 1, 2024. 5 

======== 

LC001556 

========



 

 

 

LC001556 - Page 11 of 11 

EXPLANATION 

BY THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL 

OF 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE 

HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION 

***

This act would prohibit gender transition procedures for all minors, use of public funds for 1 

that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of 2 

limitation, and right to a civil action for damages.  3 

This act would take effect on January 1, 2024. 4 

======== 

LC001556 

========

column4: Gender Reassignment, Minors
column5: Amend The South Carolina Code Of Laws By Enacting The "south Carolina's Children Deserve Help Not Harm Act" By Adding Article 3 To Chapter 47, Title 40 So As To Prohibit Physicians, Other Health Care Providers, And Health Care Facilities From Providing Or Facilitating The Provision Of Gender Transition Procedures On Minors Under The Age Of Eighteen, To Prohibit The Use Of Public Funds For Such Gender Transition Procedures, To Provide For Professional Discipline For Violation Of The Provisions Of This Article, To Create A Private Right Of Action For Violation Of The Provisions Of This Article And To Establish Damages That May Be Awarded, And To Authorize The Attorney General To Enforce The Provisions Of This Article; By Adding Section 38-71-295 So As To Prohibit Health Benefit Plans And Health Carriers From Reimbursing For Gender Transition Procedures On Minors Under The Age Of Eighteen; And For Other Purposes.

2023-2024 Bill 4619 Text of Previous Version (Nov. 16, 2023) - South Carolina Legislature Online

South Carolina General Assembly
125th Session, 2023-2024
Bill 4619

Indicates Matter Stricken
Indicates New Matter

(Text matches printed bills. Document has been reformatted to meet World Wide Web specifications.)




 


 


 


 


 


 


 


 


A bill


 


TO AMEND THE SOUTH CAROLINA CODE OF LAWS by ENACTing THE
"SOUTH CAROLINA'S CHILDREN DESERVE HELP NOT HARM ACT" BY ADDING ARTICLE 3 TO
CHAPTER 47, TITLE 40 SO AS TO PROHIBIT PHYSICIANS, OTHER HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS,
AND HEALTH CARE FACILITIES FROM PROVIDING OR FACILITATING THE PROVISION OF
GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES ON MINORS UNDER THE AGE OF EIGHTEEN, TO PROHIBIT
THE USE OF PUBLIC FUNDS FOR such GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES, TO PROVIDE FOR
PROFESSIONAL DISCIPLINE FOR VIOLATION of the provisions of this article, TO
CREATE A PRIVATE RIGHT OF ACTION FOR VIOLATION OF THE PROVISIONS OF THIS
ARTICLE AND TO ESTABLISH DAMAGES THAT MAY BE AWARDED, AND TO AUTHORIZE THE
ATTORNEY GENERAL TO ENFORCE THE PROVISiONS OF THIS ARTICLE; BY ADDING SECTION
38-71-295 SO AS TO PROHIBIT HEALTH BENEFIT PLANS AND HEALTH CARRIERS FROM
REIMBURSING  FOR GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES on MINORS under the age of
eighteen; AND FOR OTHER PURPOSES.


 


Be it enacted by the
General Assembly of the State of South Carolina:


 


SECTION 1.  This act may be cited as the "South Carolina's Children Deserve Help Not
Harm Act".


 


SECTION 2.  Chapter 47, Title 40 of the S.C. Code is amended by
adding:


 


    Article 3


 


    Gender Reassignment of Minors 


 


    Section
40-47-310. For purposes of this article:


    (1)
"Biological sex" means the biological indication of male or female in the
context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes,
naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and nonambiguous internal and
external genitalia present at birth, including secondary sex characteristics.


    (2)
"Cross-sex hormones" means:


       (a)
testosterone or other androgens given to biological females in amounts that
create serum levels greater than would normally occur naturally in healthy
biological females, which may include, but are not limited to, the following
risks:


           (i)
irreversible infertility;


           (ii)
severe liver dysfunction;


           (iii)
coronary artery disease, including heart attacks;


           (iv)
increased risk of breast, cervical, and uterine cancers;


           (v)
cerebrovascular disease, including strokes;


           (vi)
hypertension;


           (vii)
erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells;


           (viii)
sleep apnea;


           (ix)
type 2 diabetes;


           (x)
bone density loss; and


           (xi)
destabilization of psychiatric disorders; and


       (b)
estrogen given to biological males in amounts that create serum levels greater
than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological males, which may
include, but are not limited to, the following risks:


           (i)
irreversible infertility;


           (ii)
thromboembolic disease, including blood clots;


           (iii)
cholelithiasis, including gallstones;


           (iv)
coronary artery disease, including heart attacks;


           (v)
type 2 diabetes;


           (vi)
breast cancer;


           (vii)
macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland;


           (viii)
cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; and


           (ix)
hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood.


    (3)
"Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of
being male or female.


    (4)
"Gender reassignment surgery" means any surgical service that seeks to
surgically alter or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or
features that are typical for the individual's biological sex in order to
instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a
sex different from the individual's biological sex including, but not limited
to, genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose
of assisting an individual with a gender transition.


    (5)
"Gender transition" means the process in which an individual goes from
identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to his or her
biological sex to identifying with and living as a gender different from his or
her biological sex and may involve social, legal, or physical changes.


    (6)(a) "Gender transition procedure"
means any medical or surgical service including, but not limited to,
physician's services, inpatient and outpatient hospital services,
puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or genital or nongenital gender
reassignment surgery, that is provided or performed for the purpose of
assisting an individual with a physical gender transition.


       (b)
The term "gender transition procedure" does not include:


           (i)
services to individuals born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex
development including, but not limited to, an individual with external
biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as those
born with the conditions of 46, XX with virilization, 46, XY with
undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue;


           (ii)
services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed an individual with a
disorder of sexual development and determined through genetic or biochemical
testing that the individual does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex
steroid production, or sex steroid hormone action;


           (iii)
the acute or chronic treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder
that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition
procedures regardless of whether the gender transition procedure was performed
in accordance with state and federal law or whether funding for the gender
transition procedure is permissible under Section 40-47-340; or


           (iv)
any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical
disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a
physician, place the individual in imminent danger of death or impairment of a
major bodily function unless surgery is performed.


    (7)
"Genital gender reassignment surgery" means a surgical procedure performed for
the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition
including, but not limited to:


       (a)
surgical procedures such as penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty,
clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male patients; or


       (b)
surgical procedures such as hysterectomy, oophorectomy, reconstruction of the
urethra, metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty,
implantation of erection prostheses, or implantation of testicular prostheses
for biologically female patients.


    (8)
"Health care professional" means an individual who is licensed, certified, or
otherwise authorized by the laws of this State to administer health care in the
ordinary course of the practice of his or her profession, including mental
health care providers.


    (9)
"Nongenital gender reassignment surgery" means surgical procedures performed
for the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition
including, but not limited to:


       (a)
surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation
mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice
feminization surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair
reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or


       (b)
surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous
mastectomy, voice masculinization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral
implants, or various aesthetic procedures.


    (10)
"Physician" means an individual who is licensed to practice medicine in this
State.


    (11)
"Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or
other synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone
secretion and therefore testosterone production, or synthetic drugs used in
biological females that stop the production of estrogen and progesterone, when
used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children for the purpose of
assisting an individual with a gender transition.


    (12)
"Public funds" means state, county, or local governmental monies, including any
such monies deposited with or derived from any department, agency, or
instrumentality authorized or appropriated under state law.


 


    Section
40-47-320. (A) A physician or other
health care professional shall not provide gender transition procedures to any
individual under eighteen years of age.


    (B) A
health care institution or entity shall not facilitate the provision of gender
transition procedures to any individual under eighteen years of age.


 


    Section
40-47-330. (A) A person or entity,
including employees of other state governments, the federal government, or
foreign governments, shall not knowingly engage in conduct that aids or abets
the performance or inducement of gender transition procedures on any individual
under eighteen years of age.


    (B)
The provisions of this section do not apply to any speech protected by the
First Amendment of the United States Constitution.


    (C)
No parent of a child victim may be held liable under this section.


 


    Section
40-47-340. (A) Public funds shall
not be used, granted, paid, or distributed, directly or indirectly, to any
individual, entity, or organization that provides gender transition procedures
to an individual under eighteen years of age.


    (B)
Health care services furnished in the following situations shall not include
gender transition procedures to an individual under eighteen years of age:


       (1)
by or in a facility owned by the State or a county or local government; or


       (2)
by a physician or other health care professional employed by the State or a
county or local government.


    (C)
Any amount paid by an individual or an entity during a tax year for the
provision of gender transition procedures or as premiums for health care
coverage that includes coverage for gender transition procedures is not tax
deductible. The South Carolina Healthy Connections program shall not reimburse
or provide coverage for gender transition procedures to an individual under
eighteen years of age.


 


    Section
40-47-350. Any referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to an
individual under eighteen years of age is unprofessional conduct and shall be
subject to discipline by the appropriate licensing entity or disciplinary
review board with competent jurisdiction in this State.


 


    Section
40-47-360. (A)(1) Notwithstanding any other
provision of law, an individual under eighteen years of age may bring an action
under this article throughout the individual's minority through a parent or
next friend and may bring an action under this article in the individual's own
name upon reaching the age of majority at any time from that point until thirty
years after reaching the age of majority.


       (2)
If at the time the individual abused attains the age of eighteen years he or
she is under other legal disability, the limitation period under item (1) does
not begin to run until the removal of the disability.


       (3)
The limitation period in item (1) does not run during a time period when the
individual is subject to threats, intimidation, manipulation, fraudulent
concealment, or fraud perpetrated by the physician or other health care
professional who prescribed or otherwise provided gender transition procedures
or by any person acting in the interest of the physician or other health care
professional.


    (B)(1) An individual may assert an actual
or threatened violation of this article as a claim or defense in a judicial or
administrative proceeding.


       (2)
The following damages may be awarded to a claimant described in this section:


           (a)
compensatory damages including, but not limited to, pain and suffering, loss of
reputation, loss of income, and loss of consortium including, but not limited
to, the loss of expectation of sharing parenthood;


           (b)
injunctive relief;


           (c)
declaratory relief;


           (d)
punitive damages; and


           (e)
any other appropriate relief.


        (3)
A prevailing party who establishes a violation of this article shall recover
reasonable attorney's fees.


    (C)
Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action under this article may be
commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding without regard
to whether the individual commencing the action has sought or exhausted
available administrative remedies.


    (D)(1) The Attorney General may bring an
action to enforce compliance with this article.


       (2)
The provisions of this article shall not be construed to deny, impair, or
otherwise affect any right or authority of the Attorney General, the State, or
any agency, officer, or employee of the State, acting under any law other than
as provided in this article, to institute or intervene in any proceeding.


 


SECTION 3.  Article 1, Chapter 71, Title 38 of the S.C. Code is
amended by adding:


 


    Section
38-71-295. (A) For purposes of this
section:


       (1)
"Gender transition procedure" has the same meaning given to the term in Section
40-47-310.


       (2)
"Health benefit plan" means a policy, contract, certificate or agreement entered
into, offered or issued by a health carrier to provide, deliver, arrange for,
pay for, or reimburse any of the costs of health care services; except that,
health benefit plan does not include any coverage pursuant to liability
insurance policy, workers' compensation insurance policy, or medical payments
insurance issued as a supplement to a liability policy.


       (3)
"Health carrier" means an entity that provides health insurance coverage in
this State and an insurance company, a health maintenance organization, and any
other entity providing health insurance coverage which is licensed to engage in
the business of insurance in this State and which is subject to state insurance
regulation.


    (B) A
health carrier or health benefit plan that offers or issues health benefit
plans that are delivered, issued for delivery, continued, or renewed in this State
on or after the effective date of this section shall not include reimbursement
for gender transition procedures for an individual under eighteen years of age.


    (C) A
health carrier or health benefit plan that offers or issues health benefit
plans that are delivered, issued for delivery, continued, or renewed in this State
on or after the effective date of this section shall not be required to provide
coverage for gender transition procedures.


    (D) A
federal health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing
health care coverage, such as TriCare or Veterans Administration health care,
shall not include reimbursement for gender transition procedures for an
individual under eighteen years of age in this State.


 


SECTION 4.  This act takes effect six months
after approval by the Governor.

 STATE OF OKLAHOMA 

 

1st Session of the 59th Legislature (2023) 

 

HOUSE BILL 1011 By: Olsen 

 

 

 

 

 

AS INTRODUCED 

 

An Act relating to public health and safety; defining 

terms; prohibiting certain health care professionals 

from performing or attempting to perform gender 

transition procedures to certain individuals; 

prohibiting certain health care professionals from 

making certain referrals; providing exceptions; 

prohibiting use of public funds for gender transition 

procedures; prohibiting gender transition procedures 

under certain circumstances; prohibiting state 

Medicaid program reimbursements; providing for felony 

penalties; authorizing fine or confinement or both; 

prescribing statute of limitations; defining certain 

conduct as unprofessional; requiring revocation of 

license or certificate; prescribing statute of 

limitations for disciplinary proceedings; authorizing 

certain claims or defenses; prescribing statute of 

limitations; authorizing civil actions by minors; 

authorizing civil actions after majority; authorizing 

certain actions without exhaustion of administrative 

remedies; authorizing attorney fees; authorizing 

Attorney General to bring enforcement actions; 

providing for construction of act; providing for 

codification; and providing an effective date. 

 

 

 

 

 

BE IT ENACTED BY THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA: 

SECTION 1.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607.1 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows:

 As used in this act: 

1.  "Biological sex" means the biological indication of male and 

female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as 

sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and 

nonambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, 

without regard to an individual's psychological, chosen, or 

subjective experience of gender; 

2.  "Cross-sex hormones" means: 

a. testosterone or other androgens given to biological 

females in amounts that are larger or more potent than 

would normally occur naturally in healthy biological 

sex females, and 

b. estrogen given to biological males in amounts that are 

larger or more potent than would normally occur 

naturally in healthy biological sex males; 

3.  "Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social, and 

cultural aspects of being male or female; 

4.  "Gender reassignment surgery" means any medical or surgical 

service that seeks to surgically alter or remove healthy physical or 

anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the 

individual's biological sex, in order to instill or create 

physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex 

different from the individual's biological sex, including but not 

limited to genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery

5.  "Gender transition" means the process in which a person goes 

from identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to his 

or her biological sex to identifying with and living as a gender 

different from his or her biological sex, and may involve social, 

legal, or physical changes; 

6. a. "Gender transition procedures" means any medical or 

surgical service, including but not limited to 

physician's services, inpatient and outpatient 

hospital services, or prescribed drugs related to 

gender transition, that seeks to: 

(1) alter or remove physical or anatomical 

characteristics or features that are typical for 

the individual's biological sex, or 

(2) instill or create physiological or anatomical 

characteristics that resemble a sex different 

from the individual's biological sex, including 

but not limited to medical services that provide 

puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or 

other mechanisms to promote the development of 

feminizing or masculinizing features in the 

opposite biological sex, or genital or nongenital 

gender reassignment surgery performed for the

(1) services to persons born with a medically

SECTION 2.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607.2 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows: 

A.  A physician or other health care professional shall not 

perform or attempt to perform gender transition procedures to any 

individual under twenty-one (21) years of age. 

B.  A physician or other health care professional shall not 

refer any individual under twenty-one (21) years of age to any 

health care professional for gender transition procedures. 

C.  A physician or other health care professional is not 

prohibited from providing any of the following procedures which are 

not gender transition procedures to an individual under twenty-one 

(21) years of age: 

1.  Services to persons born with a medically verifiable 

disorder of sex development, including a person with external 

biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such 

as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY 

chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and 

testicular tissue; 

2.  Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a 

disorder of sexual development that the physician has determined 

through genetic or biochemical testing that the person does not have

SECTION 3.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified

result in the loss of such funding. 

B.  Health care services furnished in the following situations 

shall not include gender transition procedures to an individual 

under twenty-one (21) years of age:

C.  The state Medicaid program shall not reimburse or provide

SECTION 4.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607.4 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows: 

A.  1.  As provided in subsection A of Section 2 of this act, a 

physician or other health care professional performing or attempting 

to perform gender transition procedures to any individual under 

twenty-one (21) years of age shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a 

felony punishable by fine not to exceed One Hundred Thousand Dollars 

($100,000.00), or by confinement in the custody of the Department of 

Corrections for a term not to exceed ten (10) years, or by both such 

fine and imprisonment. 

2.  Prosecution for a criminal violation of this subsection 

shall be commenced not later than the date as of which the 

individual receiving gender transition procedures attains the age of 

forty-five (45) years. 

B.  1.  As provided in subsection B of Section 2 of this act, a 

physician or other health care professional found to have knowingly

C.  1.  Any referral for or provision of gender transition

SENATE BILL 129 By: Bullard 

 

 

 

 

 

AS INTRODUCED 

 

An Act relating to health care; creating the

procedures; providing exceptions; prohibiting certain

testicular tissue;

SECTION 5.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607.5 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows: 

A.  1.  A physician or other healthcare professional found to 

have knowingly referred for or provided gender transition procedures 

to an individual under twenty-six (26) years of age shall, upon 

conviction, be guilty of a felony. 

2.  Prosecution for a criminal violation of this subsection must 

be commenced within forty (40) years after the commission of such 

offense. 

B.  1.  Any referral for or provision of gender transition 

procedures to an individual under twenty-six (26) years of age is 

unprofessional conduct and shall, upon an adverse ruling by the 

appropriate licensing board, result in immediate revocation of the 

license or certificate of the physician or other healthcare 

professional.

STATE OF OKLAHOMA 

 

1st Session of the 59th Legislature (2023) 

 

SENATE BILL 878 By: Jett 

 

 

 

AS INTRODUCED 

 

An Act relating to health care; creating the Oklahoma 

Save Adolescents from Experimentation (SAFE) Act; 

providing short title; defining terms; prohibiting 

provision of or referral for gender transition 

procedures; providing exceptions; prohibiting certain 

uses of public funds, public facilities, public 

employees, and state Medicaid program; providing for 

administrative and civil enforcement; authorizing 

certain civil actions and relief; providing certain 

construction; providing for codification; and 

declaring an emergency. 

 

 

 

BE IT ENACTED BY THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA: 

SECTION 1.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607.1 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows: 

This act shall be known and may be cited as the “Oklahoma Save 

Adolescents from Experimentation (SAFE) Act”. 

SECTION 2.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607.2 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows: 

As used in this act: 

1.  “Biological sex” means the biological indication of male and 

female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as

normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or

age of majority. 

4.  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action under 

this subsection may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in a 

judicial proceeding without regard to whether the person commencing 

the action has sought or exhausted available administrative 

remedies. 

5.  In any action or proceeding to enforce a provision of this 

act, a prevailing party who establishes a violation of this act 

shall recover reasonable attorney fees. 

C.  1.  The Attorney General may bring an action to enforce 

compliance with this act. 

2.  This act does not deny, impair, or otherwise affect any 

right or authority of the Attorney General, this state, or any 

agency, officer, or employee of the state, acting under any law 

other than this act, to institute or intervene in any proceeding. 

SECTION 6.  It being immediately necessary for the preservation 

of the public peace, health or safety, an emergency is hereby 

declared to exist, by reason whereof this act shall take effect and 

be in full force from and after its passage and approval.
