 STATE OF OKLAHOMA 

 

1st Session of the 59th Legislature (2023) 

 

HOUSE BILL 1377 By: Gann 

 

 

 

 

 

AS INTRODUCED 

 

An Act relating to public health and safety; creating 

the Oklahoma Save Adolescents from Experimentation 

(SAFE) Act; defining terms; imposing duties and 

requirements; establishing liability; providing legal 

remedies; creating restrictions; providing for 

codification; and providing an effective date. 

 

 

 

 

 

 

BE IT ENACTED BY THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF OKLAHOMA: 

SECTION 1.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2606 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows: 

This act shall be known and may be cited as the "Oklahoma Save 

Adolescents from Experimentation (SAFE) Act". 

SECTION 2.     NEW LAW     A new section of law to be codified 

in the Oklahoma Statutes as Section 2607 of Title 63, unless there 

is created a duplication in numbering, reads as follows: 

A.  As used in this section: 

1.  "Biological sex" means the biological indication of male and 

female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as

nonambiguous internal and external genitalia present at birth, 

without regard to an individual's psychological, chosen or 

subjective experience of gender; 

2.  "Cross-sex hormones" means testosterone or other androgens 

given to biological females in amounts that are larger or more 

potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological 

females and estrogen given to biological males in amounts that are 

larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy 

biological males; 

3.  "Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social, and 

cultural aspects of being male or female; 

4.  "Gender reassignment surgery" means any medical or surgical 

service that seeks to surgically alter or remove healthy physical or 

anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the 

individual's biological sex, in order to instill or create 

physiological or anatomical characteristics that resemble a sex 

different from the individual's biological sex, including, but not 

limited to, genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery 

performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with gender 

transition; 

5.  "Gender transition" means the process in which a person goes 

from identifying and living as a gender that corresponds to his or 

her biological sex to identifying and living as a gender different

related to gender transition that seeks to: 

a. alter or remove physical or anatomical characteristics

Gender transition procedures do not include:

external biological sex characteristics that are 

irresolvably ambiguous, such as those born with 46 XX

D.  It shall be prohibited for any public monies to be directly

1.  A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of

reaching the age of majority.

column4: Prohibits gender transition procedures for all minors, uses of public funds for that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of limitation, right to a civil action for damages.
column5: HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION - Prohibits gender transition procedures for all minors, uses of public funds for that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of limitation, right to a civil action for damages.

2024 -- S 2703 
======== 

LC004975 

======== 

S T A T E   O F   R H O D E   I S L A N D  

IN GENERAL ASSEMBLY 

JANUARY SESSION, A.D. 2024 

____________ 

 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE 

HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION 

Introduced By: Senator E Morgan 

Date Introduced: March 01, 2024 

Referred To: Senate Health & Human Services 

 

 

It is enacted by the General Assembly as follows: 

SECTION 1. Legislative findings and purpose. 1 

The general assembly finds that: 2 

(1) Rhode Island has a compelling government interest protecting the health and safety of 3 

its citizens, especially vulnerable children;  4 

(2) Only a small percentage of the American population experiences distress identifying 5 

with their biological sex;  6 

(3) For the small percentage of children who are gender nonconforming or experience 7 

distress identifying with their biological sex, studies consistently demonstrate that the majority 8 

come to embrace their biological sex in adolescence or adulthood, thereby rendering most medical 9 

physiological interventions unnecessary; 10 

(4) Scientific studies show that individuals experiencing distress identifying with their 11 

biological sex have often experienced severe psychopathology preceding their gender dysphoria, 12 

which indicates these individuals could benefit greatly from access to mental healthcare services; 13 

(5) Even among individuals who have undergone inpatient gender reassignment 14 

procedures, suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, and mortality rates remain markedly elevated 15 

above the background population; 16 

(6) Some healthcare professionals are prescribing puberty-blocking drugs such as 17 

gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, in order to delay the natural onset or progression of 18 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 2 of 11 

puberty in children, who experience distress identifying with their biological sex: 1 

(i) Puberty-blocking drugs are being prescribed, despite the lack of any long-term 2 

longitudinal studies evaluating the risks and benefits of using these drugs for the treatment of such 3 

distress or gender dysphoria; and 4 

(ii) Puberty-blocking drugs are being prescribed in an off-label and experimental manner 5 

on children; 6 

(7) Some healthcare professionals are also prescribing cross-sex hormones for children 7 

who are experiencing distress identifying with their biological sex, despite the fact no randomized 8 

clinical trials have been conducted on the efficacy or safety of the use of cross-sex hormones in 9 

adults or children for the purpose of gender transition; 10 

(8) The use of cross-sex hormones comes with serious known risks: 11 

(i) For biological females, some risks may include; 12 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 13 

(B) Severe liver dysfunction; 14 

(C) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 15 

(D) Increased risk of breast, cervical, and uterine cancers; 16 

(E) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 17 

(F) Hypertension; 18 

(G) Erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells; 19 

(H) Sleep apnea; 20 

(I) Type 2 diabetes; 21 

(J) Loss of bone density; 22 

(K) Destabilization of psychiatric disorders; and 23 

(ii) For biological males, some risks may include: 24 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 25 

(B) Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; 26 

(C) Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; 27 

(D) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 28 

(E) Type 2 diabetes; 29 

(F) Breast cancer; 30 

(G) Macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland; 31 

(H) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; and 32 

(I) Hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood; 33 

(9) Genital and non-genital gender reassignment surgeries are generally not recommended 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 3 of 11 

for children, although evidence indicates referrals for children to have such surgeries are becoming 1 

more frequent; 2 

(10) Genital gender reassignment surgery includes several irreversible invasive procedures 3 

for males and females and involves the alteration of biologically healthy and functional body parts. 4 

These procedures are generally irreversible; 5 

(i) For biological males, surgery may involve: 6 

(A) Genital reconstruction, including a penectomy, which is the removal of the penis; 7 

(B) Orchiectomy, which is the removal of the testicles; 8 

(C) Vaginoplasty, which is the construction of a vagina-like structure, typically through a 9 

penile inversion procedure; 10 

(D) Clitoroplasty which is the construction of a clitoris-like structure; and 11 

(E) Vulvoplasty, which is the construction of a vulva-like structure; 12 

(ii) For biological females, surgery may involve: 13 

(A) Hysterectomy or oophorectomy; 14 

(B) Reconstruction of the urethra; 15 

(C) Genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, which is the 16 

construction of a penis-like structure; 17 

(D) Vaginectomy, which is the removal of the vagina; 18 

(E) Scrotoplasty, which is the construction of a scrotum-like structure; and 19 

(F) Implantation of erection and/or testicular prosthesis; 20 

(iii) The complications, risks, and long-term care concerns associated with genital sex 21 

reassignment surgery, for both males and females, are numerous and complex; 22 

(iv) Non-genital sex reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures for males 23 

and females and also involves the alteration or removal of biologically health, and functional body 24 

parts: 25 

(A) For biological males, this surgery may involve: 26 

(I) Augmentation mammoplasty; 27 

(II) Facial feminization surgery; 28 

(III) Liposuction; 29 

(IV) Lipofilling; 30 

(V) Voice feminization surgery; 31 

(VI) Thyroid cartilage reduction; 32 

(VII) Gluteal augmentation; 33 

(VIII) Hair reconstruction; and 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 4 of 11 

(IX) Other aesthetic procedures; 1 

(B) For biological females, this surgery may involve: 2 

(I) Subcutaneous mastectomy; 3 

(II) Voice masculinization surgery; 4 

(III) Liposuction; 5 

(IV) Lipofilling; 6 

(V) Pectoral implants; and 7 

(VI) Other aesthetic procedures; 8 

(11) It is an accepted principle of economics and public policy that when a service or 9 

product is subsidized or reimbursed, demand for that service or product increases; and 10 

(12) It is of grave concern to this general assembly that the medical community is allowing 11 

individuals, who experience distress identifying with their biological sex, to be subjects of 12 

irreversible and drastic non-genital gender reassignment surgery and irreversible, permanently 13 

sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgeries, despite the lack of studies showing that such 14 

extreme interventions have benefits that outweigh their risks or chances of cure. In fact, they may 15 

increase the risk of suicide. 16 

SECTION 2. Title 23 of the General Laws entitled "HEALTH AND SAFETY" is hereby 17 

amended by adding thereto the following chapter: 18 

CHAPTER 100 19 

RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE HELP NOT HARM ACT 20 

23-100-1. Short title.     21 

This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Rhode Island's Children Deserve 22 

Help Not Harm Act". 23 

23-100-2. Definitions.     24 

The following definitions apply in the interpretation of the provisions of this chapter: 25 

(1) "Biological sex" means the biological indication of male and female in the context of 26 

reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, 27 

gonads, and nonambiguous internal and external genitalia, present at birth, including secondary sex 28 

characteristics. 29 

(2) "Cross-sex hormones" means: 30 

(i) Testosterone or other androgens given to biological females in amounts that create 31 

serum levels greater than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological females, which may 32 

include without limitation, the following risks: 33 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 5 of 11 

(B) Severe liver dysfunction; 1 

(C) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 2 

(D) Increased risk of breast, cervical, and uterine cancers; 3 

(E) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 4 

(F) Hypertension; 5 

(G) Erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells; 6 

(H) Sleep apnea; 7 

(I) Type 2 diabetes; 8 

(J) Loss of bone density; and 9 

(K) Destabilization of psychiatric disorders; and 10 

(ii) Estrogen given to biological males, in amounts that create serum levels greater than 11 

would normally occur naturally in healthy biological males, which may include without limitation 12 

the following risks: 13 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 14 

(B) Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; 15 

(C) Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; 16 

(D) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 17 

(E) Type 2 diabetes; 18 

(F) Breast cancer; 19 

(G) Macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland; 20 

(H) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; and 21 

(I) Hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood. 22 

(3) "Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social and cultural aspects of being male 23 

and female. 24 

(4) "Gender reassignment surgery" means any surgical service that seeks to surgically alter 25 

or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or features, that are typical for the 26 

individual's biological sex, in order to instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics, 27 

that resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex, including without limitation, 28 

genital or non-genital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an 29 

individual with a gender transition. 30 

(5) "Gender transition" means the process in which a person goes from identifying with 31 

and living as a gender that corresponds to their biological sex, and may involve social, legal, or 32 

physical changes. 33 

(6) "Gender transition procedures" means any medical or surgical service provided or 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 6 of 11 

performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition: 1 

(i) Gender transition procedures include, without limitation, physician's services, inpatient 2 

and outpatient hospital services, puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or genital or non-3 

genital gender reassignment surgery; 4 

(ii) Gender transition procedures do not include: 5 

(A) Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, 6 

including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such 7 

as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with 8 

undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue; 9 

(B) Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual 10 

development, that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the 11 

person does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid production, or sex steroid 12 

hormone action; 13 

(C) The acute and chronic treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has 14 

been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, whether or not 15 

the gender transition procedure, was performed in violation of state or federal law or whether or 16 

not funding for the gender transition procedure is prohibited pursuant to the provisions of this 17 

chapter; or  18 

(D) Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, 19 

physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the individual in 20 

imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function, unless surgery is performed. 21 

(7) "Genital gender reassignment surgery" means a surgical procedure performed for the 22 

purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition, including, without limitation: 23 

(i) Surgical procedures such as a penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or 24 

vulvoplasty for biologically male patients; or 25 

(ii) Surgical procedures such as hysterectomy, oophorectomy, reconstruction of the 26 

urethra, metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection 27 

and/or testicular protheses for biologically female patients. 28 

(8) "Non-genital gender reassignment surgery" means surgical procedures performed for 29 

the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition, including, without 30 

limitation: 31 

(i) Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, 32 

facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice feminization surgery, thyroid cartilage 33 

reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 7 of 11 

(ii) Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, 1 

voice masculinization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or various aesthetic 2 

procedures. 3 

(9) "Physician" means a person who is licensed to practice medicine in this state. 4 

(10) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or other 5 

synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion and therefore 6 

testosterone production, or synthetic drugs used in biological females, which stop the production 7 

of estrogen and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children, for 8 

the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition. 9 

(11) "Public funds" means state or local government monies, in addition to any department, 10 

agency, or instrumentality authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund in 11 

which monies are deposited. 12 

23-100-3. Gender transition procedures for minors prohibited.     13 

(a) A physician or other healthcare professional shall not provide gender transition 14 

procedures to any individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 15 

(b) A healthcare institution or entity shall not facilitate the provision of gender transition 16 

procedures to any individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 17 

23-100-4. Insurance coverage for gender transition procedures for minors prohibited.     18 

(a) A health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing healthcare 19 

coverage in this state shall not include reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a person 20 

under eighteen (18) years of age. 21 

(b) A health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing healthcare 22 

coverage in this state is not required to provide coverage for gender transition procedures. 23 

(c) A federal health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing 24 

healthcare coverage, such as TRICare or Veterans Administration Healthcare, shall not include 25 

reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a person under eighteen (18) years of age in 26 

this state. 27 

23-100-5. Prohibition on aiding or abetting.     28 

(a) A person or entity shall not knowingly engage in conduct that aids or abets the 29 

performance or inducement of gender transition procedures, to any individual under eighteen (18) 30 

years of age, including employees of other state governments, the federal government, or foreign 31 

governments. 32 

(b) This provision shall not apply to any first amendment-protected speech.  33 

(c) No parent of a child victim shall be held liable under this section. 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 8 of 11 

23-100-6. Prohibition on use of public funds for gender transition.     1 

(a) Public funds shall not be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or distributed to any 2 

entity, organization, or individual that provides gender transition procedures to an individual under 3 

eighteen (18) years of age. 4 

(b) Healthcare services furnished in the following situations shall not include gender 5 

transition procedures to an individual under eighteen (18) years of age: 6 

(1) By or in a facility owned by the state or a local government; or  7 

(2) By a physician or other healthcare professional employed by the state or local 8 

government. 9 

(c) An amount paid by an individual or an entity, during a taxable year, for provision of 10 

gender transition procedures or as premiums for healthcare coverage, that includes coverage for 11 

gender transition procedures, is not tax-deductible. 12 

(d) The state Medicaid program shall not reimburse or provide coverage for gender 13 

transition procedures to an individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 14 

23-100-7. Gender transition procedures on minors constitute unprofessional and 15 

reckless conduct.     16 

Any referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to an individual, under 17 

eighteen (18) years of age, is unprofessional conduct and is subject to discipline by the appropriate 18 

licensing entity or disciplinary review board, with competent jurisdiction in this state. 19 

23-100-8. Private cause of action.     20 

Every person who subjects or causes to be subjected any citizen of this state or other person 21 

within the jurisdiction to suffer injury by violating the provisions of this chapter shall be liable to 22 

the party injured in an action at law, suit in equity, or other appropriate proceedings for redress in 23 

the superior court of this state. The court may award attorney fees and costs to a prevailing plaintiff.  24 

23-100-9. Enforcement actions for recovery of damages suffered as a result of gender 25 

transition procedures on minors.     26 

(a) Statute of limitations: 27 

(1) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an individual under eighteen (18) years of 28 

age may bring an action, throughout their minority, through a parent or next friend, and may bring 29 

an action in their own name, upon reaching the age of majority at any time from that point until 30 

thirty (30) years after reaching the age of majority. 31 

(2) Exceptions: 32 

(i) If at the time the person abused or suffering damages as a result of acts violating the 33 

provisions of this chapter, attains the age of eighteen (18) years and is under disability by reason 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 9 of 11 

of mental incompetence or under other legal disability, the limitation period under subsection (a)(1) 1 

of this section does not begin to run until the removal of the disability; and 2 

(ii) The limitation period in subsection (a)(1) of this section does not run during a time 3 

period when the individual is subject to threats, intimidation, manipulation, fraudulent 4 

concealment, or fraud perpetrated by the physician or other healthcare professional, who prescribed 5 

or otherwise provided gender transition procedures or by any person, acting in the interest of the 6 

physician or other healthcare professional. 7 

(b) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this chapter, as a claim or 8 

defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding. 9 

(1) The following damages may be awarded to the claimant: 10 

(i) Compensatory damages, including, but not limited to: 11 

(A) Pain and suffering; 12 

(B) Loss of reputation; 13 

(C) Loss of income; and 14 

(D) Loss of consortium, including, but not limited to, the loss of expectation of sharing 15 

parenthood; 16 

(ii) Injunctive relief; 17 

(iii) Declaratory relief; 18 

(iv) Punitive damages; 19 

(v) Any other appropriate relief; and 20 

(vi) A prevailing party, who establishes a violation of this chapter shall recover reasonable 21 

attorneys' fees and cost. 22 

(c) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action under this chapter, may be 23 

commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding, without regard to whether the 24 

person commencing the action has sought or exhausted available administrative remedies. 25 

(d) The attorney general may bring an action to enforce compliance with this chapter. 26 

(e) This chapter does not deny, impair, or otherwise affect any right or authority of the 27 

attorney general, the State of Rhode Island, or any agency, officer, or employee of the state, acting 28 

under any law, other than this chapter, to institute or intervene in any proceeding. 29 

23-100-10. Right of intervention.     30 

The general assembly, by joint resolution, may appoint one or more of its members who 31 

sponsored or cosponsored this chapter in their official capacity, to intervene or defend the chapter 32 

as a matter of right, in any case in which the constitutionality or enforceability of this chapter, any 33 

portion thereof, or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant hereto, is challenged. 34 



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 10 of 11 

23-100-11. Severability.     1 

Any provision of this chapter held to be invalid or unenforceable by its terms, or as applied 2 

to any person or circumstance, shall be construed so as to give it the maximum effect, permitted by 3 

law, unless such holding, shall be one of utter invalidity or unenforceability, in which event such 4 

provision shall be deemed severable herefrom and shall not affect the remainder hereof or the 5 

application of such provision to other persons not similarly situated to or to other, dissimilar 6 

circumstances. 7 

23-100-12. Effective date.     8 

This act shall take effect on January 1, 2025, in order that minors in this state currently 9 

using puberty-blocking drugs or cross-sex hormones, shall have the time for appropriate medication 10 

tapering and discontinuation, under the care of their physician or other healthcare professional. 11 

SECTION 3. This act shall take effect on January 1, 2025. 12 

======== 

LC004975 

========



 

 

 

LC004975 - Page 11 of 11 

EXPLANATION 

BY THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL 

OF 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE 

HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION 

***

This act would prohibit gender transition procedures for all minors, use of public funds for 1 

that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of 2 

limitation, and right to a civil action for damages. 3 

This act would take effect on January 1, 2025. 4

column4: Prohibits gender transition procedures for all minors, uses of public funds for that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of limitation, right to a civil action for damages.

column20:
2024 -- H 7884 
======== 

LC005368 

======== 

S T A T E   O F   R H O D E   I S L A N D  

IN GENERAL ASSEMBLY 

JANUARY SESSION, A.D. 2024 

____________ 

 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE 

HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION 

Introduced By: Representatives P. Morgan, Quattrocchi, and Rea 

Date Introduced: March 04, 2024 

Referred To: House Health & Human Services 

 

 

It is enacted by the General Assembly as follows: 

SECTION 1. Legislative findings and purpose. 1 

The general assembly finds that: 2 

(1) Rhode Island has a compelling government interest protecting the health and safety of 3 

its citizens, especially vulnerable children;  4 

(2) Only a small percentage of the American population experiences distress identifying 5 

with their biological sex;  6 

(3) For the small percentage of children who are gender nonconforming or experience 7 

distress identifying with their biological sex, studies consistently demonstrate that the majority 8 

come to embrace their biological sex in adolescence or adulthood, thereby rendering most medical 9 

physiological interventions unnecessary; 10 

(4) Scientific studies show that individuals experiencing distress identifying with their 11 

biological sex have often experienced severe psychopathology preceding their gender dysphoria, 12 

which indicates these individuals could benefit greatly from access to mental healthcare services; 13 

(5) Even among individuals who have undergone inpatient gender reassignment 14 

procedures, suicide rates, psychiatric morbidities, and mortality rates remain markedly elevated 15 

above the background population; 16 

(6) Some healthcare professionals are prescribing puberty-blocking drugs such as 17 

gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues, in order to delay the natural onset or progression of 18 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 2 of 11 

puberty in children, who experience distress identifying with their biological sex: 1 

(i) Puberty-blocking drugs are being prescribed, despite the lack of any long-term 2 

longitudinal studies evaluating the risks and benefits of using these drugs for the treatment of such 3 

distress or gender dysphoria; and 4 

(ii) Puberty-blocking drugs are being prescribed in an off-label and experimental manner 5 

on children; 6 

(7) Some healthcare professionals are also prescribing cross-sex hormones for children 7 

who are experiencing distress identifying with their biological sex, despite the fact no randomized 8 

clinical trials have been conducted on the efficacy or safety of the use of cross-sex hormones in 9 

adults or children for the purpose of gender transition; 10 

(8) The use of cross-sex hormones comes with serious known risks: 11 

(i) For biological females, some risks may include; 12 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 13 

(B) Severe liver dysfunction; 14 

(C) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 15 

(D) Increased risk of breast, cervical, and uterine cancers; 16 

(E) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 17 

(F) Hypertension; 18 

(G) Erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells; 19 

(H) Sleep apnea; 20 

(I) Type 2 diabetes; 21 

(J) Loss of bone density; 22 

(K) Destabilization of psychiatric disorders; and 23 

(ii) For biological males, some risks may include: 24 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 25 

(B) Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; 26 

(C) Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; 27 

(D) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 28 

(E) Type 2 diabetes; 29 

(F) Breast cancer; 30 

(G) Macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland; 31 

(H) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; and 32 

(I) Hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood; 33 

(9) Genital and non-genital gender reassignment surgeries are generally not recommended 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 3 of 11 

for children, although evidence indicates referrals for children to have such surgeries are becoming 1 

more frequent; 2 

(10) Genital gender reassignment surgery includes several irreversible invasive procedures 3 

for males and females and involves the alteration of biologically healthy and functional body parts. 4 

These procedures are generally irreversible; 5 

(i) For biological males, surgery may involve: 6 

(A) Genital reconstruction, including a penectomy, which is the removal of the penis; 7 

(B) Orchiectomy, which is the removal of the testicles; 8 

(C) Vaginoplasty, which is the construction of a vagina-like structure, typically through a 9 

penile inversion procedure; 10 

(D) Clitoroplasty which is the construction of a clitoris-like structure; and 11 

(E) Vulvoplasty, which is the construction of a vulva-like structure; 12 

(ii) For biological females, surgery may involve: 13 

(A) Hysterectomy or oophorectomy; 14 

(B) Reconstruction of the urethra; 15 

(C) Genital reconstruction including metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, which is the 16 

construction of a penis-like structure; 17 

(D) Vaginectomy, which is the removal of the vagina; 18 

(E) Scrotoplasty, which is the construction of a scrotum-like structure; and 19 

(F) Implantation of erection and/or testicular prosthesis; 20 

(iii) The complications, risks, and long-term care concerns associated with genital sex 21 

reassignment surgery, for both males and females, are numerous and complex; 22 

(iv) Non-genital sex reassignment surgery includes various invasive procedures for males 23 

and females and also involves the alteration or removal of biologically health, and functional body 24 

parts: 25 

(A) For biological males, this surgery may involve: 26 

(I) Augmentation mammoplasty; 27 

(II) Facial feminization surgery; 28 

(III) Liposuction; 29 

(IV) Lipofilling; 30 

(V) Voice feminization surgery; 31 

(VI) Thyroid cartilage reduction; 32 

(VII) Gluteal augmentation; 33 

(VIII) Hair reconstruction; and 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 4 of 11 

(IX) Other aesthetic procedures; 1 

(B) For biological females, this surgery may involve: 2 

(I) Subcutaneous mastectomy; 3 

(II) Voice masculinization surgery; 4 

(III) Liposuction; 5 

(IV) Lipofilling; 6 

(V) Pectoral implants; and 7 

(VI) Other aesthetic procedures; 8 

(11) It is an accepted principle of economics and public policy that when a service or 9 

product is subsidized or reimbursed, demand for that service or product increases; and 10 

(12) It is of grave concern to this general assembly that the medical community is allowing 11 

individuals, who experience distress identifying with their biological sex, to be subjects of 12 

irreversible and drastic non-genital gender reassignment surgery and irreversible, permanently 13 

sterilizing genital gender reassignment surgeries, despite the lack of studies showing that such 14 

extreme interventions have benefits that outweigh their risks or chances of cure. In fact, they may 15 

increase the risk of suicide. 16 

SECTION 2. Title 23 of the General Laws entitled "HEALTH AND SAFETY" is hereby 17 

amended by adding thereto the following chapter: 18 

CHAPTER 100 19 

RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE HELP NOT HARM ACT 20 

23-100-1. Short title.     21 

This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Rhode Island's Children Deserve 22 

Help Not Harm Act". 23 

23-100-2. Definitions.     24 

The following definitions apply in the interpretation of the provisions of this chapter: 25 

(1) "Biological sex" means the biological indication of male and female in the context of 26 

reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, 27 

gonads, and nonambiguous internal and external genitalia, present at birth, including secondary sex 28 

characteristics. 29 

(2) "Cross-sex hormones" means: 30 

(i) Testosterone or other androgens given to biological females in amounts that create 31 

serum levels greater than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological females, which may 32 

include without limitation, the following risks: 33 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 5 of 11 

(B) Severe liver dysfunction; 1 

(C) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 2 

(D) Increased risk of breast, cervical, and uterine cancers; 3 

(E) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; 4 

(F) Hypertension; 5 

(G) Erythrocytosis, which is an increase in red blood cells; 6 

(H) Sleep apnea; 7 

(I) Type 2 diabetes; 8 

(J) Loss of bone density; and 9 

(K) Destabilization of psychiatric disorders; and 10 

(ii) Estrogen given to biological males, in amounts that create serum levels greater than 11 

would normally occur naturally in healthy biological males, which may include without limitation 12 

the following risks: 13 

(A) Irreversible infertility; 14 

(B) Thromboembolic disease, including blood clots; 15 

(C) Cholelithiasis, including gallstones; 16 

(D) Coronary artery disease, including heart attacks; 17 

(E) Type 2 diabetes; 18 

(F) Breast cancer; 19 

(G) Macroprolactinoma, which is a tumor of the pituitary gland; 20 

(H) Cerebrovascular disease, including strokes; and 21 

(I) Hypertriglyceridemia, which is an elevated level of triglycerides in the blood. 22 

(3) "Gender" means the psychological, behavioral, social and cultural aspects of being male 23 

and female. 24 

(4) "Gender reassignment surgery" means any surgical service that seeks to surgically alter 25 

or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or features, that are typical for the 26 

individual's biological sex, in order to instill or create physiological or anatomical characteristics, 27 

that resemble a sex different from the individual's biological sex, including without limitation, 28 

genital or non-genital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an 29 

individual with a gender transition. 30 

(5) "Gender transition" means the process in which a person goes from identifying with 31 

and living as a gender that corresponds to their biological sex, and may involve social, legal, or 32 

physical changes. 33 

(6) "Gender transition procedures" means any medical or surgical service provided or 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 6 of 11 

performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition: 1 

(i) Gender transition procedures include, without limitation, physician's services, inpatient 2 

and outpatient hospital services, puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or genital or non-3 

genital gender reassignment surgery; 4 

(ii) Gender transition procedures do not include: 5 

(A) Services to persons born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, 6 

including a person with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such 7 

as those born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with 8 

undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue; 9 

(B) Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual 10 

development, that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the 11 

person does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid production, or sex steroid 12 

hormone action; 13 

(C) The acute and chronic treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has 14 

been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, whether or not 15 

the gender transition procedure, was performed in violation of state or federal law or whether or 16 

not funding for the gender transition procedure is prohibited pursuant to the provisions of this 17 

chapter; or  18 

(D) Any procedure undertaken because the individual suffers from a physical disorder, 19 

physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the individual in 20 

imminent danger of death or impairment of major bodily function, unless surgery is performed. 21 

(7) "Genital gender reassignment surgery" means a surgical procedure performed for the 22 

purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition, including, without limitation: 23 

(i) Surgical procedures such as a penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or 24 

vulvoplasty for biologically male patients; or 25 

(ii) Surgical procedures such as hysterectomy, oophorectomy, reconstruction of the 26 

urethra, metoidioplasty or phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection 27 

and/or testicular protheses for biologically female patients. 28 

(8) "Non-genital gender reassignment surgery" means surgical procedures performed for 29 

the purpose of assisting an individual with a physical gender transition, including, without 30 

limitation: 31 

(i) Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, 32 

facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice feminization surgery, thyroid cartilage 33 

reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, or various aesthetic procedures; or 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 7 of 11 

(ii) Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, 1 

voice masculinization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or various aesthetic 2 

procedures. 3 

(9) "Physician" means a person who is licensed to practice medicine in this state. 4 

(10) "Puberty-blocking drugs" means gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or other 5 

synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion and therefore 6 

testosterone production, or synthetic drugs used in biological females, which stop the production 7 

of estrogen and progesterone, when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in children, for 8 

the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition. 9 

(11) "Public funds" means state or local government monies, in addition to any department, 10 

agency, or instrumentality authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund in 11 

which monies are deposited. 12 

23-100-3. Gender transition procedures for minors prohibited.     13 

(a) A physician or other healthcare professional shall not provide gender transition 14 

procedures to any individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 15 

(b) A healthcare institution or entity shall not facilitate the provision of gender transition 16 

procedures to any individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 17 

23-100-4. Insurance coverage for gender transition procedures for minors prohibited.     18 

(a) A health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing healthcare 19 

coverage in this state shall not include reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a person 20 

under eighteen (18) years of age. 21 

(b) A health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing healthcare 22 

coverage in this state is not required to provide coverage for gender transition procedures. 23 

(c) A federal health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing 24 

healthcare coverage, such as TRICare or Veterans Administration Healthcare, shall not include 25 

reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a person under eighteen (18) years of age in 26 

this state. 27 

23-100-5. Prohibition on aiding or abetting.     28 

(a) A person or entity shall not knowingly engage in conduct that aids or abets the 29 

performance or inducement of gender transition procedures, to any individual under eighteen (18) 30 

years of age, including employees of other state governments, the federal government, or foreign 31 

governments. 32 

(b) This provision shall not apply to any first amendment-protected speech.  33 

(c) No parent of a child victim shall be held liable under this section. 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 8 of 11 

23-100-6. Prohibition on use of public funds for gender transition.     1 

(a) Public funds shall not be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or distributed to any 2 

entity, organization, or individual that provides gender transition procedures to an individual under 3 

eighteen (18) years of age. 4 

(b) Healthcare services furnished in the following situations shall not include gender 5 

transition procedures to an individual under eighteen (18) years of age: 6 

(1) By or in a facility owned by the state or a local government; or  7 

(2) By a physician or other healthcare professional employed by the state or local 8 

government. 9 

(c) An amount paid by an individual or an entity, during a taxable year, for provision of 10 

gender transition procedures or as premiums for healthcare coverage, that includes coverage for 11 

gender transition procedures, is not tax-deductible. 12 

(d) The state Medicaid program shall not reimburse or provide coverage for gender 13 

transition procedures to an individual under eighteen (18) years of age. 14 

23-100-7. Gender transition procedures on minors constitute unprofessional and 15 

reckless conduct.     16 

Any referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to an individual, under 17 

eighteen (18) years of age, is unprofessional conduct and is subject to discipline by the appropriate 18 

licensing entity or disciplinary review board, with competent jurisdiction in this state. 19 

23-100-8. Private cause of action.     20 

Every person who subjects or causes to be subjected any citizen of this state or other person 21 

within the jurisdiction to suffer injury by violating the provisions of this chapter shall be liable to 22 

the party injured in an action at law, suit in equity, or other appropriate proceedings for redress in 23 

the superior court of this state. The court may award attorney fees and costs to a prevailing plaintiff.  24 

23-100-9. Enforcement actions for recovery of damages suffered as a result of gender 25 

transition procedures on minors.     26 

(a) Statute of limitations: 27 

(1) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an individual under eighteen (18) years of 28 

age may bring an action, throughout their minority, through a parent or next friend, and may bring 29 

an action in their own name, upon reaching the age of majority at any time from that point until 30 

thirty (30) years after reaching the age of majority. 31 

(2) Exceptions: 32 

(i) If at the time the person abused or suffering damages as a result of acts violating the 33 

provisions of this chapter, attains the age of eighteen (18) years and is under disability by reason 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 9 of 11 

of mental incompetence or under other legal disability, the limitation period under subsection (a)(1) 1 

of this section does not begin to run until the removal of the disability; and 2 

(ii) The limitation period in subsection (a)(1) of this section does not run during a time 3 

period when the individual is subject to threats, intimidation, manipulation, fraudulent 4 

concealment, or fraud perpetrated by the physician or other healthcare professional, who prescribed 5 

or otherwise provided gender transition procedures or by any person, acting in the interest of the 6 

physician or other healthcare professional. 7 

(b) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this chapter, as a claim or 8 

defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding. 9 

(1) The following damages may be awarded to the claimant: 10 

(i) Compensatory damages, including, but not limited to: 11 

(A) Pain and suffering; 12 

(B) Loss of reputation; 13 

(C) Loss of income; and 14 

(D) Loss of consortium, including, but not limited to, the loss of expectation of sharing 15 

parenthood; 16 

(ii) Injunctive relief; 17 

(iii) Declaratory relief; 18 

(iv) Punitive damages; 19 

(v) Any other appropriate relief; and 20 

(vi) A prevailing party, who establishes a violation of this chapter shall recover reasonable 21 

attorneys' fees and cost. 22 

(c) Notwithstanding any other provision of law, an action under this chapter, may be 23 

commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding, without regard to whether the 24 

person commencing the action has sought or exhausted available administrative remedies. 25 

(d) The attorney general may bring an action to enforce compliance with this chapter. 26 

(e) This chapter does not deny, impair, or otherwise affect any right or authority of the 27 

attorney general, the State of Rhode Island, or any agency, officer, or employee of the state, acting 28 

under any law, other than this chapter, to institute or intervene in any proceeding. 29 

23-100-10. Right of intervention.     30 

The general assembly, by joint resolution, may appoint one or more of its members who 31 

sponsored or cosponsored this chapter in their official capacity, to intervene or defend the chapter 32 

as a matter of right, in any case in which the constitutionality or enforceability of this chapter, any 33 

portion thereof, or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant hereto, is challenged. 34 



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 10 of 11 

23-100-11. Severability.     1 

Any provision of this chapter held to be invalid or unenforceable by its terms, or as applied 2 

to any person or circumstance, shall be construed so as to give it the maximum effect, permitted by 3 

law, unless such holding, shall be one of utter invalidity or unenforceability, in which event such 4 

provision shall be deemed severable herefrom and shall not affect the remainder hereof or the 5 

application of such provision to other persons not similarly situated to or to other, dissimilar 6 

circumstances. 7 

23-100-12. Effective date.     8 

This act shall take effect on January 1, 2025, in order that minors in this state currently 9 

using puberty-blocking drugs or cross-sex hormones, shall have the time for appropriate medication 10 

tapering and discontinuation, under the care of their physician or other healthcare professional. 11 

SECTION 3. This act shall take effect on January 1, 2025. 12 

======== 

LC005368 

========



 

 

 

LC005368 - Page 11 of 11 

EXPLANATION 

BY THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL 

OF 

A N   A C T 

RELATING TO HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE 

HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION 

***

This act would prohibit gender transition procedures for all minors, use of public funds for 1 

that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of 2 

limitation, and right to a civil action for damages. 3 

This act would take effect on January 1, 2025. 4

## EXPLANATION

## BY THE LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL

OF

## A N   A C T

## RELATING TO HEALTH AND SAFETY -- RHODE ISLAND'S CHILDREN DESERVE HELP NOT HARM ACT -- MINOR'S GENDER TRANSITION

## ***

- This act would prohibit gender transition procedures for all minors, use of public funds for 1
- that purpose, discipline for health care providers for providing same, a thirty (30) year statute of 2
- limitation, after reaching the age of majority, and right to a civil action for damages. 3
- This act would take effect on January 1, 2026. 4

column4: An Act To Amend Title 16 Of The Delaware Code Relating To Gender Transition Procedures.
column5: This Act prohibits gender transition surgery for children due to the potential for an irrevocable procedure occurring when there is a significant probability that children will come to identify with their biological gender.
column18: {"Bryant Richardson","Jeff Hilovsky","Gerald Hocker","David Lawson","David Wilson","Richard Collins","Ronald Gray","Shannon Morris","Bryan Shupe","Lyndon Yearick"}
column20:
SPONSOR:

Sen. Richardson & Rep. Hilovsky

Sens. Hocker, Lawson, Wilson; Reps. Collins, Gray, Morris, Shupe, Yearick

DELAWARE STATE SENATE

153rd GENERAL ASSEMBLY

SENATE BILL NO. 55

AN ACT TO AMEND TITLE 16 OF THE DELAWARE CODE RELATING TO GENDER TRANSITION PROCEDURES.

BE IT ENACTED BY THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY OF THE STATE OF DELAWARE:

Section 1. Amend Part II, Title 16 of the Delaware Code by making deletions as shown by strike through and insertions as shown by underline as follows:

Chapter 30R. The Delaware Save Adolescents From Experimentation Act.

§ 3001R. Title.

This chapter is known and may be cited as the “Delaware Save Adolescents From Experimentation (SAFE) Act”.

§ 3002R. Legislative Findings.

The General Assembly finds as follows:

(1) The State has a compelling governmental interest in protecting the health and safety of its citizens, especially vulnerable children.

(2) Less than 1% of the American population experiences difficulty at identifying with their biological sex.

(3) Studies demonstrate that the majority of children who gender nonconforming or experience difficulty identifying with their biological sex come to identify with their biological sex in adolescence or adulthood, rendering most physiological interventions unnecessary.

(4) Despite a lack of studies demonstrating the long-term risk and benefits to using puberty-blocking drugs, some healthcare providers are prescribing puberty-blocking drugs to delay the onset or progression of puberty in children who experience difficulty identifying with their biological sex.

(5) The United Kingdom’s National Health Service has banned the use of puberty blocking drugs for children who are gender nonconforming or experience difficulty identifying with their biological sex.

(6) Other healthcare providers prescribe cross-sex hormones for such children, despite known health risks.

(7) Genital and nongenital reassignment surgeries, despite non typically being recommended for children, are becoming more frequent.

§ 3003R. Definitions.

As used in this chapter:

(1) “Biological sex” means the biological indication of male or female in the context of reproductive potential or capacity, such as sex chromosomes, naturally occurring sex hormones, gonads, and nonambiguous internal and external genetalia present at birth, without regard to an individual’s psychological, chosen, or subjective experience of gender.

(2) “Cross-sex hormones” means all of the following:

a. Testosterone or other androgens given to biological females in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological females.

b. Estrogen given to biological males in amounts that are larger or more potent than would normally occur naturally in healthy biological males.

(3) “Gender” means the psychological, behavioral, social, and cultural aspects of being male or female.

(4) “Gender reassignment surgery” means any medical or surgical service that seeks to surgically alter or remove healthy physical or anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the individual’s biological sex to instill or create physical or anatomical characteristics or features that resemble a sex different from the individual’s biological sex, including genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.

(5) “Gender transition” means the process in which an individual goes from identifying with and living as a gender that corresponds to the individual’s biological sex to identifying with and living as a gender different from the individual’s biological sex, and may involve social, legal, or physical changes.

(6) “Gender transition procedure” means a medical or surgical service, including physician services, inpatient and outpatient hospital services, or prescribed drugs related to gender transition, that seeks to do any of the following:

a. Alter or remove physical or anatomical characteristics or features that are typical for the individual’s biological sex.

b. Instill or create physical or anatomical characteristics or features that resemble a sex different from the individual’s biological sex, including medical services that provide puberty-blocking drugs, cross-sex hormones, or other mechanisms to promote the development of feminizing or masculinizing features in the opposite biological sex, or genital or nongenital gender reassignment surgery performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.

(7)a. “Genital gender reassignment surgery” means a medical procedure performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.

b. “Genital gender reassignment surgery” includes any of the following:

1. Surgical procedures such as penectomy, orchiectomy, vaginoplasty, clitoroplasty, or vulvoplasty for biologically male patients or hysterectomy or ovariectomy for biologically female patients.

2. Reconstruction of the fixed part of the urethra with or without a metoidioplasty.

3. Phalloplasty, vaginectomy, scrotoplasty, or implantation of erection or testicular prostheses for biologically female patients.

(8) “Healthcare professional” means an individual who is licensed, certified, or otherwise authorized by the laws of this State to administer health care in the ordinary course of the practice of the individual’s profession.

(9)a. “Nongenital gender reassignment surgery” means medical procedures performed for the purpose of assisting an individual with a gender transition.

b. “Nongenital gender reassignment surgery” includes any of the following:

1. Surgical procedures for biologically male patients, such as augmentation mammoplasty, facial feminization surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, voice surgery, thyroid cartilage reduction, gluteal augmentation, hair reconstruction, or other aesthetic procedures.

2. Surgical procedures for biologically female patients, such as subcutaneous mastectomy, voice surgery, liposuction, lipofilling, pectoral implants, or other aesthetic procedures.

(10) “Physician” means an individual who is licensed to practice medicine in this State.

(11) “Puberty-blocking drugs” means all of the following when used to delay or suppress pubertal development in a child for the purpose of assisting the child with a gender transition:

a. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone analogues or other synthetic drugs used in biological males to stop luteinizing hormone secretion and therefore testosterone secretion.

b. Synthetic drugs used in biological females which stop the production of estrogen and progesterone.

(12) “Public funds” means State, county, or local government monies, in addition to any department, agency, or instrumentality authorized or appropriated under state law or derived from any fund in which such monies are deposited.

§ 3004R. Prohibition of gender transition procedures for child; exceptions.

(a) A physician or other healthcare professional may not provide gender transition procedures to a child.

(b) A physician or other healthcare professional may not refer a child to a healthcare professional for gender transition procedures.

(c) A physician or other healthcare professional may provide any of the following procedures to a child:

(1) Services to the child who is born with a medically verifiable disorder of sex development, including a child with external biological sex characteristics that are irresolvably ambiguous, such as a child born with 46 XX chromosomes with virilization, 46 XY chromosomes with undervirilization, or having both ovarian and testicular tissue.

(2) Services provided when a physician has otherwise diagnosed a disorder of sexual development that the physician has determined through genetic or biochemical testing that the child does not have normal sex chromosome structure, sex steroid hormone production, or sex steroid hormone action.

(3) The treatment of any infection, injury, disease, or disorder that has been caused by or exacerbated by the performance of gender transition procedures, whether or not the gender transition procedure was performed under state and federal law or whether or not funding for the gender transition procedure is permissible under this chapter.

(4) Any procedure undertaken because the child suffers from a physical disorder, physical injury, or physical illness that would, as certified by a physician, place the child in imminent danger or death or impairment of a major bodily function unless surgery is performed.

§ 3005R. Prohibition on use of public funds.

(a) Public funds may not be directly or indirectly used, granted, paid, or distributed to an entity, organization, or individual that provides gender transition procedures to a child.

(b) Healthcare services furnished in the following situations may not include gender transition procedures for a child:

(1) By or in a healthcare facility owned by the State or a county or local government.

(2) By a physician or other healthcare professional employed by the State or a county or local government.

(c) The Delaware Medicaid Program may not reimburse or provide coverage for gender transition procedures to a child.

§ 3006R. Enforcement.

(a) A referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to a child is unprofessional conduct. A physician or healthcare professional who makes a referral for or provides gender transition procedures to a child is subject to discipline by the appropriate licensing entity or disciplinary review board with jurisdiction over the physician or healthcare professional in this State.

(b) A person may assert an actual or threatened violation of this chapter as a claim or defense in a judicial or administrative proceeding and obtain compensatory damages, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief.

(c) Except as provided under paragraph (c)(2) of this section, an individual must bring a claim for a violation of this chapter not later than 2 years after the day the cause of action accrues.

(1) A child may bring an action through a parent or guardian.

(2) An individual who was a child when the cause of action accrued may bring an action in the individual’s own name on reaching full age and at any time from that point until 20 years after reaching full age.

(d) Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, an action under this chapter may be commenced, and relief may be granted, in a judicial proceeding without regard to whether the person commencing the action has sought or exhausted available administrative remedies.

(e) In any action or proceeding to enforce a provision of this chapter, a court shall grant reasonable attorneys’ fees to a prevailing party who establishes a violation of this chapter.

(f) The Attorney General may bring an action to enforce compliance with this chapter. This chapter does not deny, impair, or otherwise affect any right or authority of the Attorney General, the State, or any agency, officer, or employee of the State, acting under any law other than this chapter, to institute or intervene in any proceeding.

§ 3007R. Insurance coverage of gender transition procedures.

Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, a health benefit plan under an insurance policy or other plan providing healthcare coverage issued in this State may not include reimbursement for gender transition procedures for a child.

SYNOPSIS

This Act prohibits gender transition surgery for children due to the potential for an irrevocable procedure occurring when there is a significant probability that children will come to identify with their biological gender.

This Act prohibits the use of public funds and insurance coverage for gender transition surgery for children.

This Act provides for enforcement of the Act as follows:

(1) By providing for compensatory damages, injunctive relief, declaratory relief, or any other appropriate relief.

(2) By making a referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to a child unprofessional conduct for which a physician or healthcare professional making the referral for or provision of gender transition procedures to a child is subject to discipline by the appropriate licensing entity or disciplinary review board with jurisdiction over the physician or healthcare professional in this State.

Author: Senator Richardson
